conclusion: Analyze refraction angles and relationship between refractive index and concentration.
Light bends when passing between media, described by Snell's Law: n1 sin(θ) = n2 sin(β).
Incident angle θ is the same for both glasses; refraction angles differ: β1 > β2; refractive index increases with sucrose concentration.
Apply Snell's Law for glass A and B: n1 sin(θ) = nA sin(β1) and n1 sin(θ) = nB sin(β2).
Rearrange Snell's Law to find refractive indices: nA = n1 sin(θ) / sin(β1) and nB = n1 sin(θ) / sin(β2).
Refractive index increases with concentration; since nA < nB, concentration in glass A is lower.
The concentration of sucrose water in cup A is lower than in cup B.
